H0.text: Weathering is the process in which freezing and expanding water in cracks of rocks causes the rocks to break apart.

H1.text: Deposition is the process that describes the freezing and expanding of water in the cracks of rocks.

H2.text: Faulting is the process of freezing and expanding water in the cracks of rocks.

H3.text: Erosion is the process of freezing and expanding water in the cracks of rocks.

A4.text: When water freezes, its volume increases by 9.2%.

A5.text: Ice will simply expand out of a straight open fracture before it can generate significant pressure, thus frost wedging can only take place in small tortuous fractures.

A6.text: At a temperature of -22 °C, ice growth is known to be able to generate pressures of up to 207 MPa, more than enough to fracture any rock.

A7.text: The ice crystal growth weakens the rocks which, in time, break up.
